{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3554721,"name":"Ambrish","username":"ambrish3281","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ea666f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T01:40:59.284Z","cooked":"

Hello,

We are having an intake ARM which we need to keep in upright position at a certain angle until we are ready to move it with a joystick.

We are brainstorming ideas of using limit switch etc…
Any suggestions/guidance on any other better approach to achieve it ?

Thanks Much!
Ambrish

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T01:40:59.284Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495241,"topic_slug":"example-java-code-to-keep-arm-at-a-fixed-angle","display_username":"Ambrish","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70872,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/example-java-code-to-keep-arm-at-a-fixed-angle/495241/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554734,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T01:59:29.894Z","cooked":"

The standard way of doing so is a technique called “closed-loop control”. PID is a very common example of this. You would need some kind of feedback device (i.e. an encoder) to tell your code where the arm is, then you would command it to the angle you want. The code will “close the loop” by constantly calculating the error (measured position minus intended position) and using that to deternine how much power to apply to the motor.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

PID Control in WPILib

WPILib supports PID control of mechanisms through the PIDController class ( Java, C++, Python). This class handles the feedback loop calculation for the user, as well as offering methods for return...

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T03:06:25.701Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":12.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495241,"topic_slug":"example-java-code-to-keep-arm-at-a-fixed-angle","display_username":"icemannie","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/controllers/pidcontroller.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PID Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28240,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/example-java-code-to-keep-arm-at-a-fixed-angle/495241/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554782,"name":"Kade Rabe","username":"Kadd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kadd/{size}/178400_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T03:26:43.203Z","cooked":"

if you are using a motor with an internal encoder like a NEO, Falcon, or Kraken you should use the built in positional control methods PID/MotionMagic/MAXMotion, PID is simplest, read up on the examples/documentation for this. if you are using a motor like a CIM or 775, try to implement some type of Encoder sensor like a CANCoder or Rev Absolute encoder into your mechanism to read the angle of your arm and use PID to do the positional control.

You can also use a feedforward to hold the arm at a certain position. For just holding at a position, you only need a kG constant: ArmFeedforward (WPILib API 2025.3.1)

kG is the voltage / percent output needed to hold the arm horizontally. Once you find this value, call calculate (you can pass in 0 for velocity) and apply the output to the arm motors. Hope this helps!
